content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom"> <title>Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/224349" rel="alternate"/> <subtitle/> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/224349</id> <updated>2015-03-12T02:54:17Z</updated> <dc:date>2015-03-12T02:54:17Z</dc:date> <entry> <title>Lokaratna, Volume 4</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244857" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Mishra, Mahendra Kumar</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244857</id> <updated>2013-08-27T13:40:45Z</updated> <published>2011-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Lokaratna, Volume 4 Mishra, Mahendra Kumar As the the official journal of the Folklore Foundation, Lokaratna is a bilingual, peer reviewed academic journal published in Oriya and English. Located in Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India, the Folklore Foundation promotes folklore in the public domain and is committed to quality research. The literal meaning of lokaratna is 'gem of the people', the gem being the oral traditions that are created by people through their oral expression. The editor-in-chief of the journal is Dr Mahendra Kumar Mishra. </summary> <dc:date>2011-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Lokaratna, Volume 5 and 6</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244853" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Mishra, Mahendra Kumar</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244853</id> <updated>2013-08-24T06:40:42Z</updated> <published>2013-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Lokaratna, Volume 5 and 6 Mishra, Mahendra Kumar As the the official journal of the Folklore Foundation, Lokaratna is a bilingual, peer reviewed academic journal published in Oriya and English. Located in Bhubaneswar, Orissa, India, the Folklore Foundation promotes folklore in the public domain and is committed to quality research. The literal meaning of lokaratna is 'gem of the people', the gem being the oral traditions that are created by people through their oral expression. The editor-in-chief of the journal is Dr Mahendra Kumar Mishra. </summary> <dc:date>2013-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Storytelling in Northern Zambia, 1988 - 89</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244610" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Cancel, Robert</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244610</id> <updated>2013-07-25T16:02:33Z</updated> <published>1988-01-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Storytelling in Northern Zambia, 1988 - 89 Cancel, Robert Storytelling performances collected in 1988-89 from five Bemba-speaking ethnic groups: Bemba, Bisa, Bwile, Lunda and Tabwa. Soundtrack is in original language with English subtitles.  Video material is the basis of a book-length study titled  Storytelling in Northern Zambia:  Theory, Method, Practice and Other Necessary Fictions (Cambridge:  Open Book Publishers, 2013, in the Oral Literature series, co-sponsored by the World Oral Literature Project). Digital video of storytelling performances from five Bemba-speaking groups in Zambia. </summary> <dc:date>1988-01-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> <entry> <title>Phur ba Ritual 5a</title> <link href="http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244567" rel="alternate"/> <author> <name>Mayer, Robert</name> </author> <id>http://www.repository.cam.ac.uk:80/handle/1810/244567</id> <updated>2013-07-25T12:14:39Z</updated> <published>2010-02-01T00:00:00Z</published> <summary type="text">Phur ba Ritual 5a Mayer, Robert Dr Cathy Cantwell and Dr Rob Mayer, of Oxford University,  undertook an AHRC-funded research project to study the Bon Phur pa tradition descending from the 12th century figure of Khu tsha zla \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdod. The project ran from May 2007 until December 2011. The Bon monastery of Triten Norbutse in Kathmandu  continue this ritual tradition, especially in their elaborate dgu gtor or year-ending ceremonies. Kemi Tsewang was commissioned to photograph and video the rites, held in the last week of the Tibetan year, from the preparations on 9th February 2010, through the main ritual on 10th and 11th February, up to and including the ritual dances and exorcisms on 12th February, 2010. HD movies made by Kemi Tsewang for Cathy Cantwell & Rob Mayer\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds AHRC-funded Bon Phur pa project at Oxford University. </summary> <dc:date>2010-02-01T00:00:00Z</dc:date> </entry> </feed>
